_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Routine visual inspection by trained operators
_prev_prog_3.Description: United Suppliers Inc--Pierre Sd uses the recommended matrix approach to preventing accidental releases on site.  The site is predictive filing where anhydrous ammonia is supplied by truck or railcar that is used to supply ammonia to a portable reactor.  Ammonia storage and handling is covered by OSHA's Process Safet management Standards.  In addition emloyee training and adherence to specific operations and maintenance inspections and testing ensure the continued viablilty of facility equipment.  close contact is maintained with the LEPC and other local agencies.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The United Suppliers Inc.--Pierre Sd operation is committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by continually improving both practices and measures to prevent the release of regulated substances.  In the event of a release, the Pierre facility is prepared to work with the Hughes County Commission LEPC and/or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact to people and the environment.

The Pierre facility's primary covered process activity is the mixing of fertilizers.  These activities include storage and processing of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and processed into 10-34-0 non-hazardous liquid fertilizer.  Processing is periodic and usually occurs in the spring and fall.  Ammonia mixing with phosphoric acid occurs in a T-reactor.  The T reactor is usually a contractor operation that is controlled by the contractor.  Water is used as both a reaction feed material and product stablizer.  The Emergency Response Procedures for Pierre Sd are coordinated with Hughes County Commission.

United Suppliers Inc-Pierre Sd has taken the necessary steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR part 68.  Pierre is also covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management standard.  The following briefly describes the prevention program elements in place at this stationary source.

Process Safety Information:  The unit maintains information describing the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.

Process Hazard Analysis:  Studies are conducted to ensure the hazards associated with process operations are identified, understood and controlled.

Operating Procedures:  Written operating procedures are maintained for covered process opertions.  These procedures address the following activities:  initial startup, normal, temporary, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown and startup following a turnaround.

Training

:  A program is in place to ensure employee(s) are knowledgeable and trained in procedures associated with the covered proceses.

Mechanical Integrity:  Covered process equipment is maintained consistent with generally accepted engineering practices.  Covered process equipment is routinely inspected and tested.  Maintenance activities are conducted by qualified personnel.  Deficiencies are corrected in a timely manner.

Management of Change:  Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and/or procedures.  Affected personnel are informed and trained to deal with authorized system changes.

Pre-Startup Review:  Technical and operational reviews will be conducted on new processes and/or modifications to existing covered processes.  Reviews confirm the construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable.  Reviews are completed prior to placing equipment in operation.

Compliance Audits:  Internal audits are conducted ona regular basis to determine whether the provisions specified under the RMP  rule are being implemented.  At a minimum, these audits are conducted every theree (3) years.  Any determined corrective actions are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigations:  Investigations will be conducted to determine the root cause of covered process incidents.  In addition to determination and correction, investigations are directed toward preventing reoccurances.  Investigations become process safety information and are retained for five (5) years.

Employee Participations:  Pierre Sd unit employee(s) actively contribute in the following:  process hazard assessments, operating procedure development, maintenance procedure development, training development and implementation, pre-startup reviews, incident investigations, and compliance audits.  Additionally, employee(s) have access to all information pertaining to the facility's RMP.

Contractors:  Periodically, Pierre Sd may hire contract

ors to conduct specialized operational, maintenenance and construction activities.  Prior to work, contractors are trained on the covered processes, relevant process safety information and emergency response actions.

Five (5) Year Accident History:  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five (5) years that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage.  Nor to our knowledge, has there been any releases resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage and/or environmnetal damage.

Emergency Action Plan:  United Suppliers, Inc--Pierre Sd has a written emergency action plan.  This plan includes notification of the Hughes County Commission LEPC to respond to a major release as United Suppliers, Inc--Pierre Sd does not plan on responding to a major release.  Local authorities have been provided with emergency planning and community right-to-know information.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  United Suppliers, Inc--Pierre Sd views safety improvements as a continual process.  Periodic evaluations (both internal and external) are performed to asess the facility status.  At this time, and aside from sustaining maintenance activities, there are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding anhydrous ammonia.
